data.text: Making Money while Bike Touring for Months
How do you earn while traveling for months??
Following in this one.
data.author: Patricia Seifert

data.text: same
data.author: Rivers Mitchell

data.text: I’ll busk/ Street perform, I’ve been playing music since I was 5 and I now specialise in flutes from all around the world which makes carrying my instrument small lightweight and easy. I’ve only done 2 week trips so far mind you but if a problem does arise then my backup plan is to find a seasonal job to save up and then move on
data.author: Lachlan Johnson

data.text: That sounds great! I am a novice on the flute. Maybe people would pay me to NOT play?
data.author: Michael Loftis

data.text: Well (and I mean this as a light hearted joke) there are 3 kinds of buskers, 1 is the one you throw some change into their hat cause they sound decent, 2 is the one you throw $5 in because they’re pretty great and 3 is the one you pay to shut up😂😂😂 The modest one in me tells me I’m decent, the ego tells me I’m great and the critic tells me that I’m being paid to shut up😂😂😂
data.author: Lachlan Johnson

data.author: Jamie Fellows

data.text: The first fork in the road for this question would be: legally or illegally 🤷🏻‍♂️🤔
data.author: Tom Burklow

data.text: I contacted my local newspaper and asked if they’d be interested in an article once in a while. It currently finances more than half of my expenses 😄 I’m not spending my money in hotels or expensive restaurants. I keep my costs at somewhat minimum. Probably around 4-5$ pr. day plus other expenses such as bike repairs, visas, paid accommodation (rarely) and alternative transportation. Probably around 10-12$ a day for everything. That’s another part of it. One thing is gathering finances and another part is to make them last. I see plenty of comments on other posts from people stating that it’s impossible to tour in Europe with less than 30+$ a day. It’s absolutely not true. It all comes down to how much comfort a person wants on their trip. Everything is alright - people are different with different preferences. These numbers are mostly from European countries. It has already dropped significantly after entering Turkey.
data.author: Søren Rosenius Olsen

data.text: I have had articles published- but there is no offer of payment...
data.author: Gary Roberts

data.text: That’s bad. Then the newspaper is basically freeloading by taking an article from you instead of paying a journalist to fill the same pages…
data.author: Søren Rosenius Olsen

data.text: i agree with u, i just spend 10-12 usd/d for everything, that's enough for long trip in Asia, i don't know how about Euro, maybe more.
data.author: Hoang Nam

data.text: So in June I left Spain and I worked in a bakery located in the Alpes during the month of August. Currently I am looking for a job in Bucharest. I am not rushing so I hope opportunities will come eventually.
data.author: Radu Adrian Puiu

data.text: by and large the bulk of the long term people ive met were "in between jobs",,,they saved up for their experience and even worked some odd jobs along the way,,,,the rest i met were self employed where either the company had management or they were specialists in their field like a specialty surgeon,,,,,,,,,another group were trust fund people that had inheritance
data.author: Joe Dyer

data.text: you summarized my exact experience... If I may add, on top of living "in between jobs" we forego a lot of things to make up travel money and time. No car, no house, no wife, no kids... That's me. And definitely I'm working about 8 to 9 months a year and when I travel for 3-4 months People start thinking I'm earning on the road 🤦🤦🤦🤦 yet I still live on low end budgets even on the road .
data.author: Kyagera Ivan

data.text: Retire at 62 then tour when your old I'm mentally fighting with this issue also I have enough to travel 3to 4 years so I'm 56 I will work two more years hope legs hold up and then bike the road after that.
data.author: Shawn Goodrum

data.text: A few weeks ago I met a cycle tourer in South Africa who started cycling the world when he was 59. After 9 tears he has cycled over 270 thousand kilometers... an inspiration for me as I aim to start cycling the world in a few years (I'm 55 now...)
data.author: Johan Steyn

data.text: that's like doing 2500km averagely per month or 650km a week. 270,000km?🤔🤔 Just impressive. I could do half his feat at my age of 35😄. I have just finished 30 days tour and I was doing about 450km a week. If I was going long term I would do maybe 300km a week.. His feat at his age blows my mind.. respect to him💪

data.text: Aluminum won't rust till I hit 58 and the road.
data.author: Shawn Goodrum

data.text: I worked 3 months a year from Memorial day to Labor day each year from 1980 to 2019, to self support my bike tours Sept to May. By doing this system I only worked 10 years total in those 39 years and toured 30 total years. I retired in 2019 so now Social Security supports my tours.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: what did you do for work in those 3 months?
data.author: Anthony D'Arcy

data.text: Food Service in 7 National Parks and many tourist towns like Jackson Wyoming, Lake Placid NY, Durango CO. Mainly I was a Chef.

data.text: That’s what I’m going through!
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: Has it become harder recently? Cause I've worked with hundreds of foreign employees in all the parks and places I've worked at. But it's been 3 years since I retired in 2019. Before I started bike touring I hitchhiked five years from 1977 to 1982. My first summer in 77 I hitched 10,000 miles around the USA. I took up bike touring after meeting a couple from Germany the summer of 1982 and rode 2100 mi/3379 km in 19 days. I was 26. I'm 66 now and in two weeks I'll start my 41st fall winter and spring touring.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: 750.00 a month is not enough for me

data.text: I help people maintain and improve their language skills via Skype, and I do translations. Working languages: ES, EN, JP, DE, FR. Been on the road since 2012, mostly cycling, sometimes 3 weeks or 3 months in one place, then onward. Europe, Asia, America. Average living budget: 500 EUR/month.

data.text: That's a good question, and I think most people who travel long distances by bike face it.
data.author: Daliang Zhang

data.text: I left the UK when I was 27 after working and saving money for around a year. That lasted me 2 years on the road without working. Since then I have been working a bit in whichever country I was in when I ran out of cash, then travelling with the money I made. It's worked out so far, it's been 11 years since I left the UK 😅
data.author: Tony Gahegan

data.text: inspirational stuff ! Your video diary is great . Sitting inside in the rain it’s tempting to rent the house out !
data.author: Ian Stevens

data.text: Thanks. I just started the vlog, still learning 😅 Having a place to rent out would certainly help finding a life of travel 🤣
data.author: Tony Gahegan

data.text: do you still have the same bike? 😉
data.author: Daria Baranik

data.text: The first 2 years I was on a motorbike, then a year in Australia using ride-share. Then I got my bike as a sponsorship deal from an Australian company. I've had that bike ever since. A little over 8 years. Although it didn't get much use the last couple of years before I came to South America, because of COVID lockdowns in SE Asia 🤪

data.text: No wife. No kids. No stuff (Living minimalist life). Working at least half of the year and travel in low budget... That's literally how most people manage long term travel... And that's me too
data.author: Kyagera Ivan

data.text: Sounds about right to me.
data.author: Danny Chemtov

data.text: I saved up over 5 years just to do this for 1 year.
data.author: Brice Loh

data.text: A friend of mine tours Europe on a bike as a lifestyle, he gets work through an agency, most of it manual. The deal is he gets food and accommodation ( sometimes money as well) He only has to work the morning and has the rest of the day to be tourist. He is also an artist and does murals/portraits that he gets paid for. Even so it’s a struggle, especially if the bike needs repair
data.author: Richard Bould

data.text: Step 1-Take out a personal loan (max you can get). Step 2 - take the cash out. Step 3 - declare yourself bankrupt. Step 4 - go on tour for at least 5 years while your credit resets. Step 5 - repeat steps 1,2,3,4 🤟
data.author: Mark Randlesome

data.author: Simon Jap McClelland

data.text: Get an unpaid leave from your work.
data.author: Vasily  Suvorov

data.text: We have been Warmshowers hosts for probably 14 years and one of the first people to stay with us took surveys from some soap/laundry detergent companies both online and with us. We met another couple who travelled with an RV and would go to garage sales and then resell items on eBay. We do one to three week tours and are happy to get away from work so just tour without worrying about $$$$.

data.text: save money first and see after enjoy our trip and no more calculation

Irwin Kumar

data.text: I work as a Project Manager for a Digital Marketing agency. Earlier this year we cycle toured Sri Lanka, riding in the mornings, and then me working from late afternoon to be online during UK office hours. I've traveled a lot while working, as long as I have an internet connection I'm fine! I usually tether to my phone hotspot and I have a Chromebook laptop which does everything I need and is very portable - easily fits in a pannier or even a saddlebag 🙂
data.author: Sarah Vickers

data.text: I'm in the same field
data.author: Manoj Maity

data.text: When I am running low of funds, I check the maps for the next town. Then I look for a community Facebook group and post that I will be passing thru, bicycle tour, need a little work. It won’t make me wealthy, but it keeps me fed and riding
data.author: Nesta Skychild
